metadata.label: Transcript

[Abraham Lott to Nathanael Greene
October 24, 1778
[RvW Box 2 Folder 46; MSS. – A.L.S.]]

Beverwyck  Oct.r 24th. 1778
My dear Sir
The uncertainty of finding you 
after the raising of the Blockade at Rhode Island
prevented my troubling you with any of my Letters.
but finding by your much esteemed favor of the
19th Instant, which came to hand two Days ago,
that you had returned to Fredricksburgh [sic], I could
not let slip the favorable conveyance by Colo –
Morris to Acknowledge receipt thereof –
Col.o [Colonel] Livingston , as you suppose, as well
as some other of my friends have given me an
account of the Rhode Island Expedition , and the
concurring circumstances, which were the causes
of its miscarriage – Most people seem to blame
the Comte d'Estaing  for quitting New Port so preci-
-pitately, and blame him totaly solely for the
failure of the Expedition. – However that may
be, I must own that I think he moved off rather
sooner than he need have done, and that we
should have taken the place, and made the whole
Garrison Prisoners of war, with the whole of the
Enemies Stores, if he had remained but 24 hours
longer before the place – Could we have
Succeeded in this, the whole British Army in
New York, must in my opinion, also have fallen
into our hands – The consequences of which
would have been that Britain would have
been glad to make peace with us on such
Terms as we should dictate. – It is therefore
not to be won and at that some people are a little 
vociferous, against Monsr. Le Compte d'Estaing.	
[End Page 1]
I am greatly obliged to Genl. [General] [and] Mrs
Hancock  for their remembrance of me – They showed
me the greatest marks of attention while I was
at Boston, and [I] rank them among the most
virtuous Citizens – It is true they live high,
but I do not think them Tinctured  with the
prevailing vices of the Town, mentioned by you,
[and] which I also was an Eye Witness to. Indeed
I went so far as to mention to some of my friends
that I expected from what I had always heard
to find a pius Religious set of people, but
to my surprize found very little remains of it
amongst them – A sad foreboding this, that
in times of danger and universal distress, Vice
instead of Virtue should prevail, and Especially
among a people formerly highly esteemed for
their moral, as well as Religious professions
- I pray God may not in his great displeasure
punish the Land for these growing Abomi-
-nations, but may turn the hearts of all its
Inhabitants to do what is truely [sic] praise
-worthy, and acceptable to him.
Mrs. Livingston  is perfectly recovered, and
hope to have the pleasure of seeing her here shortly –
Col.o [Colonel] Bill  has sent his Resignation to his
Excellency, which for the sake of his wife, I hope
may be Accepted – He and I expect to set out
for Phila next Monday, but do not mean to
make any stay there.
I sincerely congratulate you upon the 
birth of another Daughter , and cannot but be
[End Page 2]
Proud that you mean to honor my Daughter
Cornelia, with naming the child after her. Be
pleased to present our compliment to Mrs. Greene
upon her happy delivery, and accept my
wishes that the Child may live [and] be a comfort
to you both – Mrs. Livingston has also, lately
been brought to Bed with a son, who for
his age is a promising lad. –
You cannot doubt of my wishes to meet
you in New York soon, - But tho we have
reason from every information to believe that 
[the] Enemy are preparing to quit that City, I
[MS. blotted] make myself believe they will go off
[MS. blotted] altogether this Autumn; but
[MS. blotted] other think they will keep pos-
[-session] of that place as long as they
[po]ssibly can. – I hope I may be
[MS. blotted] and that we may take each other
[MS. blotted] there soon.
Our army moving from White Plains
shortly after I quitted the Camp [and] having been
in no fixed place since, I have not had an
opportunity to send of my [?] yet – Pray
will you do me the favor to let me know
whether, if I send it to Fishkill , any empty
return wagons to Boston can be got to take it
to that place, and where it ought to be at Fishkill[?]
Mrs. Lott [and] the family, present their best
respects to you with those of –
Dear Gen. l [General]
Your most obed.t  Servt [obedient Servant]
Abrm [Abraham] Lott
[End Page 3]
[Addressed:] The Honorable
Major Genl. N. Greene [General Nathanael Greene]
at
Favored by          Headquarters 
Col.o [Colonel] Morris        Fredricksburgh [sic]
[Endorsed upside down:]  A. Lott Esqr. [Abraham Lott Esquire]
24. Octr. 78
[End Page 4]
